awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebraic Geometry and Singularities in Positive and Mixed Characteristic
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic Geometry studies algebraic varieties which are geometric objects defined by polynomial equations. One of the most natural problems in this area is to understand the singularities that naturally occur when considering algebraic varieties and how these singularities influence the global geometry of algebraic varieties. In recent years there have been a number of breakthroughs, especially in the case where we consider solutions over the complex numbers. At the same time new techniques and approaches have emerged for studying solutions in positive and mixed characteristics. The primary goal of this collaborative project is to advance and unify these ideas to further understand and solve some of the most challenging programs in both local and global algebraic geometry. In addition the project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.
 
The PIs will investigate singularities in positive and mixed characteristics by using a variety of techniques including those arising from the minimal model program, from the theory of F-singularities, and from Scholze's work on perfectoid algebras and spaces. The PIs will also organize workshops, a summer school and a conference, aimed at training young researchers in this area, disseminating recent results and facilitating further advances and breakthroughs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported  foundational work in what is known as prime and mixed characteristic algebraic geometry. Algebraic geometry is the study of  shapes and sets that can be defined by multi-dimensional polynomial equations.

The scientific merit and broader impacts of the project flow from the fact that ,any important problems in the physical and life sciences,  engineering, and most recently data science, can be attacked by observing that certain relevant objects (e.g.,  a robotic arm  or data set) can be described---or at least approximated arbitrarily well---by polynomials, which are much easier for both humans and machines to manipulate and understand.  This is important because the mathematical theory of algebraic geometry, which has been developed over centuries and is incredible powerful,  can then be used to great advantage in solving problems. The algebraic geometry studied in this project in two settings. The first setting is  algebraic geometry over fields of prime characteristic (such as finite fields), which is an increasingly important topic in our modern digital word (for example, some error-correcting codes, the technology behind digital communication, is based on algebraic geometry over fields of two elements). The second is algebraic geometry in "mixed characteristic," which is pushing the frontier by looking at discrete multi-dimensional sets of integers defined by polynomial equations; this project was an important contributor to the rapidly developing foundations of this new subject of mathematics.

The broader impacts also include significant human resource development for the further foundational work in mathematices as well as both the public and private sectors in industries such as artifical intelligence, cyber security, and data science. The project engaged numerous PhD and ungraduate research students, as well as postdoctoral researchers in cutting edge research in algebraic geometry. These participants will transfer this knowledge to future students and colleagues at their academic and industry positions throughout the US.
